intro: Pimpinella imbricata, commonly known as the fringed cow-wheat, is a flowering plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided leaves and small, yellowish flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and stream banks. Its fruit is a dry, two-lobed capsule that releases tiny seeds when mature. Pimpinella imbricata is often found in calcareous soils and is sometimes used in traditional herbal medicine.
